awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Advanced alkaline electrolyzer stack for hydrogen peroxide onsite production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is a significant advance in the production of hydrogen peroxide. It is anticipated that this project will yield an on-site generation method that substantially reduces the cost of peroxide production compared to the traditional centralized chemical process. By reducing cost, hydrogen peroxide can be used more widely as an oxidizer in bleaching, drinking water and wastewater treatment, and other processes, ultimately lowering chlorine pollution by replacing chlorine-based oxidizers. The pulp/paper and textiles industry will benefit from lower cost bleaching chemicals and reduced treatment costs. This method reduces environmental pollution and eliminates the need for transportation of explosive high-concentration hydrogen peroxide. The new design may have applications in other industrial systems.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to demonstrate a scaled-up high efficiency alkaline hydrogen peroxide electrolyzer system. The end result will be a commercial demonstration-ready prototype. The electrode manufacturing process will be optimized for high-volume manufacturing on roll-to-roll coating lines. Electrolyzer prototypes will be built and tested at medium scale with a moderate cell count, then improved and scaled to full-size cells with a high cell count. Durability testing will be performed, including development of accelerated testing protocols, to facilitate screening of electrode materials and assess manufacturing variations implemented in roll-to-roll coating. These individual project goals will culminate in a commercial pilot-ready autonomous system for on-site generation of hydrogen peroxide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The conventional method for producing peroxide, the anthraquinone oxidation method, is complex, environmentally hazardous, and expensive. Peroxygen Systems has developed an advanced electrolyzer that can produce peroxide for lower cost and eliminate shipping and handling of dangerous concentrated peroxide. The process reduces carbon dioxide emissions for peroxide manufacturing by 50% and also completely eliminates waste byproducts.

During Phase II of the project, substantial improvements in the cathode material were made which increased durability while preserving the excellent performance and high efficiency demonstrated during Phase I of the project. Modifications to flow field design and structure also enabled improved stability and performance. Additionally, refinements to the manufacturing process were made during Phase II that enable large scale production. These steps forward have enabled Peroxygen to pursue a commercial demonstration project at a pulp mill; from there, wide-scale implementation of the technology is expected to follow.

Peroxygen’s continued development of advanced electrode structures and stack hardware that support multi-phase flow with highly efficient operation can be applied to a variety of electrochemical systems spanning energy storage and chemical synthesis.

In addition to broadly advancing the field of electrochemistry, the impact of Peroxygen's technology on reducing peroxide cost has implications in other industries. Lower cost can fundamentally disrupt the global peroxide market, enabling increased adoption across several industries including the pulp & paper, textiles, and water treatment industries. If applied to energy storage or other chemical synthesis routes such as electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction, the advanced multiphase flow electrode developed by Peroxygen could have a far-reaching environmental and climate impact.


Last Modified: 10/12/2021
Modified by: Ming Qi
